Description: Lower body sherd of East Greek Wild Goat Style pottery dinos; interior glazed streaky black; exterior: yellowish white slip; from top, upper frieze surviving only as part of triangle as filling ornament; below, wide black band; frieze of goats grazing to right (top of head and antler of goat on the left remaining, of that to the right rump, haunch, and stomach with added red).
Producer name: Made by: The London Dinos Group
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The piece bears all the characteristics of the London Dinos group, including the glazed inside and the mix of filling ornament.
Compare W. Schiering, Werkstätten orientalischer Keramik auf Rhodos, p. 123, no. 232; Walter-Karydi, 1970, p. 3, no. 8; D. Williams (pers.comm. 2009), possibly from North Ionia.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 2-3, pl. 3, no. 14)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GK.78)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
